item.title: Literature Bias in Alzheimer's Disease Clinical Trials
item.description: In 2019 I had the opportunity to share some of my research at the American Academy of Neurologists in Philadelphia. Here I’ll provide my poster as well as a few reasons for my excitement about the topic of literature bias in Alzheimer’s Disease. What This Research Contributes: The largest review of Alzheimer’s literature focusing on bias Expands on previous Funding bias research in Alzheimer’s Disease Provides non-anecdotal exploration into Publishing Journal as a source of bias Introduces Author Affiliations as a potential biasing factor Background In clinical research, the Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT) is considered the gold standard due to it’s ability to mitigate the amount of bias introduced by investigators and patients.

item.title: Parallel Plots for Exploratory Analysis of Clinical Trial Literature Reviews
item.description: In the pursuit of more data-centric medical decisions large scale literature reviews are increasingly necessary, however, results of these literature reviews are often hard to depict outside of numeric tables. I’ll be exploring the use of parallel plots as a complementary reporting tool for literature reviews through their ability to display hundreds of clinical trials on a single graph. This idea was inspired by an excellent set of plots from 538.

Summary Highly motivated data professional with 4+ years of experience utilizing R and Python for statistics, predictive analytic, and machine learning. Skilled in managing data operations and implementing solutions from collection to modeling. Proven ability to communicate the impact of analytical findings to a wide range of audiences through innovative data visualizations.
